abstract.para: Instances are virtual machines that run inside the cloud. To start an instance, you must have a virtual machine image that contains the following information: which operating system to use, a user name and password with which to log in to the &vmguest;, file storage etc. The cloud contains a pool of such images that have been uploaded and made accessible to members of different projects. If you want to make the virtual machine accessible from outside the cloud, you need to configure security groups. If needed, block storage devices (volumes) can be attached to a running instance (or detached and attached to another instance at any time).

sect1.title: Managing Images
sect1.para: Images cannot be added from the &cloud; ‐, you need to use the command line tool glance add instead. For details, refer to .

sect1.title: Launching Instances
sect1.para: After images have been uploaded to Glance, you can launch instances that are based on those images. Upon start, you need to specify the following key parameters:

listitem.para: The size (flavor) of the virtual machine.

A keypair for SSH access of the instance. For details, refer to . In case an image uses a static &rootuser; password or a static key set (neither is recommended), you do not need to provide a keypair on start of the instance.
A security group that the instance should belong to. Security groups are a kind of cloud firewall that define which incoming network traffic should be forwarded to instances. For details, refer to .

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Images & Snapshot category. The ‐ shows the Images that have been uploaded to Glance and are available for this project.
Select an image and click Launch.
In the window that opens, specify the following:
Enter a Server Name that will be assigned to the virtual machine.
From the Flavor drop-down list, select the size of the virtual machine to launch.
Select a Keypair.
In Instance Count, enter the number of virtual machines to launch from this image.
Activate the Security Groups that you want to assign to the instance. If you did not create any specific security groups, you can only assign the instance to the default security group.
Click Launch Instance. The instance will be started on any of the &compnode;s in the cloud.

sect1.para: After you have launched an instance, switch to the Instances & Volumes catgory view the Instance Name, its (private or public) IP address, its Size, its Status, Task, and Power State.

sect1.title: Configuring Access to the Instances
sect1.para: For SSH access to an instance, you usually need to provide a keypair at launch time and to adjust the security rules. The default security rules block access to SSH ports and prevent pinging an instance. To make the instance also accessible from outside the cloud, assign a floating (public) IP address.

sect2.title: Creating or Importing Keys
sect2.para: Keypairs are SSH credentials that are injected into images when they are launched. Create at least one keypair per project. If you already generated a keypair with an external tool, you can import it into &ostack;. The keypair can be used for multiple instances belong to that project.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
To import a keypair that you have generated with an external tool:
Click Import Keypair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the keypair and copy the public key into the respective input field.
Confirm your choice.
To create a new keypair:
Click Create Keypair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the keypair and confirm your choice.
&ostack; generates a keypair and provides the private key for download as a *.pem file.
Save the *.pem file locally and change its permissions so that only you can read and write to the file:

sect2.para: The public key of the keypair is registered at the Nova database. The ‐ lists the keypair in the Access & Security category as shown in .

sect2.title: Configuring Security Groups and Rules
sect2.para: In &productname;, security groups are used to define which incoming network traffic should be forwarded to instances. Security groups hold a set of firewall policies (security goup rules).

sect3.title: Security Groups
sect3.para: When launching an instance, you need to define which security groups it should belong to. A default security group is available for each project. It allows all network traffic from other members of this group and discards traffic from other IP addresses and groups.

Multiple security groups for a project can be defined, with each group holding a different set of firewall policies. This is useful if you have groups of instances that should differ in firewall configuration (for example, front-end and back-end servers). An instance can be assigned to multiple security groups.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
To create a new security group:
Click Create Security Group.
In the window that opens, enter a Name and Description for the group and confirm your changes.
To delete one or multiple security groups:
Activate the check boxes in front of the groups that you want to delete.
Click Delete Security Groups and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.

note.title: Deleting Security Groups
note.para: The default security group for a project cannot be deleted.
In case another group cannot be deleted, it is still assigned to a running instance. To change that:

listitem.para: Switch to the Instances & Volumes category to view instances that have been launched.
Click the instances' name links to view details such as the security group that is assigned to the respective instance.
Terminate the instance belonging to the security group that you want to delete. Relaunch the instance and assign it to another security group.

sect3.title: Security Group Rules
sect3.para: You can adjust rules of the default security group as well as rules of any other security group that has been created. As soon as the rules for a group are modified, the new rules are automatically applied to all running instances belonging to that security group.

Adjust the rules in a security group to allow access to instances via different ports and protocols. This is necessary to be able to access instances via SSH, to ping them or to allow UDP traffic (for example, for an DNS server running on an instance.)
Rules in security groups are specified by the following parameters:

listitem.para: Decide if to allow traffic to instances only from IP addresses inside the cloud (from other group members) or from all IP addresses.
Choose between TCP (for SSH), ICMP (for pings), or UDP.

Define a port range. To open a single port only, enter the same value twice. ICMP does not support ports. In that case, enter values which define the codes and types of ICMP traffic that should be allowed.

sect3.para: If no further security groups have been created, any instances are automatically assigned to the default security group (if not specified otherwise). Unless you change the rules for the default group, this means that those instances are only accessible from IP addresses belonging to other members of this group. They cannot be accessed from any IP addresses outside.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
Select the group to modify and click Edit Rules. The window that appears shows which rules have already been configured.
To allow SSH access to the instances:
Set IP Protocol to TCP.
Enter the value 22 in both From Port and To Port.
To allow access from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.
To allow pinging the instances:
Set IP Protocol to ICMP.
Enter the value -1 in both From Port and To Port. This allows access to all codes and all types of ICMP traffic, respectively.
To allow access from all IP addresses (0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only members of other security groups to ping instances. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.
To allow access via UDP port (for example, for an DNS server running on a VM):
Set IP Protocol to UDP.
Enter the value 53 in both From Port and To Port.
To allow access from all IP addresses (0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.

sect2.title: Managing IP Addresses
sect2.para: Each instance can have two IP addresses: a private and a public one. Private IP addresses are used for communication between instances, public ones for communication with the outside world. When an instance is launched, it is automatically assigned a private IP address which stays the same until the instance is explicitly terminated.taroth 2012-08-22: DEVs: does an instance also lose its private IP on reboot?

From the pool of floating IPs available in &ostack; Nova, you can allocate a number of floating IP address to a project (the limit is defined by the quota). Then you can add a floating IP address an instance of that project. Floating IP addresses can be dynamically disassociated and associated with other instances at any time. taroth 2012-08-21: DEVs, whose task is it to create floating IPs in the first place? admin? operator? and is there more than the Nova pool to allocate IPs from?

procedure.title: Allocating Floating (Public) IPs to a Project
procedure.para: Before you can assign a floating IP address to an instance, you first need to allocate floating IPs to a project.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows a list of Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the current project.
To allocate a floating IP address to the current project:
Click Allocate IP to Project.
In the window that opens, select a Pool out of which to take the IP address.
Click Allocate IP.
The ‐ shows the allocated IP addresses in the Access & Security category. The first IP shown for an instance is the private IP address, the second one is the floating IP address.
To release one or multiple floating IP addresses from a project:
Activate the check boxes in front of the IP addresses that you want to release.

Click Release Floating IPs. The IP addresses are put back into the pool of IP addresses that are available for all projects. If an IP address is currently assigned to a running instance, it will automatically be dissociated from the instance.

procedure.title: Assigning Floating (Public) IP Addresses to Instances
procedure.para: After floating IP addresses have been allocated to the current project, you can assign them to running instances. One floating IP address can be assigned to an instance at a time.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows a list of Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the current project.
Select an IP address and click Associate IP.
In the window that opens, select the Instance to associate the IP with and confirm your choice.

In the Access & Security category, the list of Floating IPs shows the ID of the instance with which the IP has been associated. The instance is now publically available under the respective floating IPs address (provided you have also configured the security groups rules for the instance accordingly). For details, refer to .

sect1.title: Managing Instances
sect1.para: The following are typical tasks for managing instances:

listitem.para: Accessing instances from remote
Viewing logs
Creating instance snapshots to preserve a certain disk state of an instance
Using instance snaphots as base for new images
Rebooting or terminating instances
Passing or suspending instances
Using volumes for persistent storage

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance and from the Actions drop-down list, select View Log.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the Log tab that opens.
The ‐ shows the output of the instance's serial console. To make use of this feature, the respective image must have set the serial console correctly in &grub;.

sect2.title: Accessing Instances from Remote
sect2.para: The ‐'s built-in VNC client allows you to access instances at any time.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance tho access and from the Actions drop-down list, select VNC Console.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the VNC tab that opens.
To display a larger VNC screen, use the link Click here to show only VNC.
To leave the large VNC screen, use the back button of the browser.

sect2.para: DEVs, is the following correct? To access an instance via SSH, the following requirements need to be fulfilled:

listitem.para: The security group which the instance is assigned to, must be configured to allow SSH access. For details, refer to .
To allow SSH access from outside the cloud, a floating IP address must be assigned to the instance. For details, refer to .

You must know the private or public IP address of the instance. To look it up, log in to &cloud; ‐. On the Project tab, switch to the Instances & Volumes category. If only one IP address is shown for the instance, it is the private IP address (for communication inside the cloud). If a second IP address is shown, the second one is the public (floating) IP address.

sect2.title: Using Instance Snapshots
sect2.para: Snapshots preserve the disk state of a running instance. taroth 2012-08-21: DEVs, if I got it right, ephemeral disks are generally excluded from the snapshots? You can launch a new instance from a snapshot or use a snapshot to create a new image based upon the snapshot.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance for which to create a snapshot. From the Actions drop-down list, select Snapshot.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the snapshot and confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the new Instance Snapshot in the Images & Snapshot category.
To launch a new instance from the snapshot, select the snapshot and click Launch. Proceed with launching an instance as described in .

procedure.title: Basing an Image on a Snapshot

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Images & Snapshots category.
Select the snapshot and from the Actions drop-down list, select Edit.
In the window that opens, enter the image properties. For more information, refer to .
Click Update Image.

‐ shows the newly created image in the list of images in the Images & Snapshot category. If you delete the snapshot, upon which the image is based, the image will be deleted as well. If you delete the image, the snapshot upon which it is based, will be deleted as well.

sect2.title: Pausing, Suspending, Rebooting or Terminating Instances
sect2.para: For maintenance reasons, you can pause or suspend images—provided they are running on &kvm; or &xen;. Pausing or suspending avoids the consequences that come with terminating or rebooting an instance.

important.title: Risk of Data Loss
important.para: taroth 2012-08-21: DEVs, is the following correct? Terminating or rebooting an instance has the following consequences:

listitem.para: All data on the image's root disk and ephemeral disks are destroyed. To prevent that, use volumes and attach them to an instance for persistent storage.
If a floating IP address was assigned to that instance, the IP adress is disassociated from that image. However, it is still available in the pool of allocated IP addresses for the current project.

sect2.para: If you pause an instance, the content of the virtual machine is stored to memory (RAM) and the image is kept running in a frozen state. When suspending an instance, the contents of the virtual machine is stored to disk and memory and vCPUS are freed.

step.para: Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance which to put out of the running state. From the Actions drop-down list, select the respective action.
